questions.text: Identify the INCORRECT match of disease & organism among the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D.  Erysipelas- Pseudomonas

 

Option D. 

 

Erysipelas is caused by Group A Beta Hemolytic streptococcus NOT pseudomonas.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae.

 

  • It is a Gram-positive bacillus that feeds primarily on dead animal matter, causes an acute infection known as Erysipeloid.
  • It infects many animals, particularly pigs, with diseases. Fishermen, farmers, farmers, butchers, cooks, veterinarians, and farmers are typically affected.
  • Erysipeloid depicted in the image below:

 

 

  • A hot, tender, violaceous erythema that spreads centrifugally forms around the inoculation site about three days after the inoculation.
  • Without treatment, healing normally occurs spontaneously in 2 weeks without desquamation or suppuration.
  • Antibiotic therapy: Penicillin, erythromycin, and ciprofloxacin

 

Option B:  Pitted keratolysis.

 

  • It is caused most commonly due to infection by Corynebacterium / Kytococcus sedentarius.
  • The pits are produced by serine proteases that can degrade keratin in the horny layer.

 

 

  • It is usually associated with hyperhidrosis.
  • Treatment of hyperhidrosis slowly brings the condition under control including potassium permanganate soaks, aluminium chloride, and iontophoresis.
  • Topical Fucidin ointment may be used.

 

Option C: Scrub typhus

 

  • Aetiology: Orientia tsutsugamushi
  • Vector: trombiculid mite
  • Infective form of mite: chiggers (larval form)
  • Clinical presentation: presents to Causality with fever, CNS symptoms.
  • Lesion: Eschar (erythema surrounding black scab).

 

Eschar is seen in the below image with black scab at centre surrounded by erythema.

 

 

Differential diagnosis of Eschar:

 

  1. Cutaneous anthrax
  2. Brown recluse spider bite (poisonous spider)
  3. Scrub typhus

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Erysipelas is an infection commonly caused by Group A Streptococcus, not Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I

Chapter 26, Page nos 26.42-26.43, 26.46

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1276

choices.text: Bullous impetigo is the other name for this disease
Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism
Golden yellow or honey-coloured crusts are seen associated with this disease
Superficial intraepidermal bulla are formed as desmoglein-1 is targeted by the exfoliative toxins

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents to the clinic with several fluid-filled blisters on the skin and some areas with a varnish-coloured crust. The infant does not appear to be in significant discomfort, and the rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Given the clinical presentation and the age of the infant, which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Golden yellow- or honey-coloured crusts are seen associated with this disease

The clinical picture described—a 2-month-old infant with fluid-filled blisters and varnish coloured crusts—is classic for bullous impetigo, a localized superficial skin infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus. The exfoliative toxins released by the bacteria specifically target desmoglein-1 of the epidermis. This results in the formation of superficial intraepidermal bullae that rupture easily, leaving a varnish-like crust, rather than the golden yellow or honey-coloured crusts that are seen in non-bullous impetigo.

Other options:

  • A. Bullous impetigo is the other name for this disease:
    This is a true and appropriate statement. The condition described aligns with the presentation of bullous impetigo, and it is correctly named as such.
  • B. Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism:
    Accurate. The organism Staphylococcus aureus is responsible for bullous impetigo, owing to its production of exfoliative toxins.

  • D. Superficial intraepidermal bulla are formed as desmoglein-1 is targeted by the exfoliative toxins:
    This is a correct pathophysiological mechanism explaining how the bullae form in this condition. 

     

Pemphigus neonatorum / Bullous impetigo:

 

  • It is the most likely diagnosis from the given clinical case scenario.

  • It is caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

  • Impetigo is a contagious, superficial pyogenic infection of the skin.

  • Superficial intraepidermal bulla are formed as desmoglein-1 is targeted by the exfoliative toxins produced by S. aureus.

  • After the bulla rupture, they leave behind varnish crust (NOT Golden yellow or honey-coloured crusts).

  • Below image depicts Bullous Impetigo with intact bullae & Varnish coloured crusts.

  • Hypopyon Sign - The pus gravitates to the lower half of the bulla. 

 

 

Complication:

 

Hematogenous spread of Exfoliative toxin can lead to Ritter's disease/Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS).

 

Impetigo management:

 

  • Treatment involves topical Fucidin or mupirocin, retapamulin in resistant cases.

  • Systemic therapy with flucloxacillin and erythromycin may be given.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigus neonatorum, or bullous impetigo, typically presents with varnish-like crusts rather than golden yellow or honey-colored crusts after bullae rupture.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition

Chapter 26, Page nos 26.14-26.15

questions.text: All of the following are bacterial infections of skin EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Impetigo herpetiformis

 

Option C.

 

Impetigo herpetiformis (It is not a bacterial infection)

 

  • It is generalised Pustular Psoriasis in pregnancy.
  • Severe acute form of psoriasis associated with fever chills, with sudden appearance of fiery red erythema followed by waves of tiny superficial sterile pustules as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • It Resolves after delivery.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Ecthyma pyogenicum

 

  • It is a pyogenic infection of the skin characterized by the formation of adherent crusts, beneath which ulceration occurs.
  • It most commonly results from mixed infection of group A streptococci > staphylococci and causes a deeper infection than impetigo.
  • The buttocks, thighs, and legs are most affected.

 

Risk factors include:

 

  • Extremes of age
  • Immunocompromised
  • Diabetes
  • Poor hygiene.

 

Treatment: Topical Fucidin, topical mupirocin, and systemic cloxacillin.

 

Option B: Ecthyma gangrenosum

 

It is caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which manifests as hemorrhagic pustules that evolve into a necrotic (black) ulcer which can be seen in the image below.

 

 

Option D: Trichomycosis axillaris (now referred to as Trichobacteriosis axillaris)

 

  • It is caused by Corynebacterium tenuis.
  • It is a superficial infection of axillary and pubic hairs with the formation of yellow, black, or red nodular concretions on the hair shaft.
  • Trichobacteriosis. Tan-yellow concretions on the hair shafts of the axilla.

 

 

  • Depending on the colour of the concretions, the axillary sweat may be yellow, black, or red, and the clothing may be stained.
  • Since the condition frequently has no symptoms, the patient is frequently unaware of its existence.
  • The use of an effective antiperspirant such as aluminium chloride is a rapid means of therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Impetigo herpetiformis, despite its name, is not a bacterial infection but a form of pustular psoriasis seen in pregnancy.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition

Chapter 26, Page no 26.16-26.17, 26.41, 26.51

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology textbook 9th edition Chapter 105 page no 1771

choices.text: Topical steroids have an important role in treatment of chronic paronychia.
It is Infection of nail folds.
Candida is the most common causative organism in chronic paronychia.
Streptococcus pyogenes is the most common causative organism in acute paronychia.

questions.text: True about Paronychia are all EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Streptococcus pyogenes is the most common causative organism in acute paronychia.

 

Option D.

 

  • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common causative organism in acute paronychia NOT streptococcus.

 

Acute paronychia:

 

  • It is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It is an infection of the nail fold which is characterised by inflammation, swelling and abscess formation.
  • Diagnosis is clinical and a cover of systemic antibiotics may be needed for deep infections.
  • Candida albicans is the most common causative organism in chronic paronychia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staphylococcus aureus, not Streptococcus pyogenes, is the most common causative organism of acute paronychia.

 

Ref: Fitzpatrick’s Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition chapter 150 page no 2725

questions.text: Staphylococcus aureus causes or associated with all of the following EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Scarlet fever

 

Option D.

 

Scarlet fever:

 

  • It Presents with a generalised rash often with co-existing Streptococcal pharyngitis.

 

 

Mnemonic for features of scarlet fever:

 

S - Streptococcal sore throat: Etiology

C - Circumoral pallor: Skin

A - Antecubital fossa petechiae → Pastia lines: Skin

R - Rash (sandpaper): Skin

L - Lymphadenopathy: General examination

E - Erythrogenic toxin: Pathogenesis

T - Tongue (strawberry): Mucosa

 

Explanation:

 

Option A "Botryomycosis"

 

  • It is a misnomer.
  • It is an infection brought on by bacteria, usually staphylococcus.
  • It is a chronic granulomatous reaction to bacterial infection that manifests as multiple skin abscesses with mucopurulent discharge through multiple sinuses.
  • The discharge contains granules that resemble the sulphur granules found in actinomycosis and does not reveal filamentous organisms when stained with Gomori methenamine silver (GMS negative).

 

Below image depicts Botryomycosis with multiple skin abscesses with mucopurulent discharge through multiple sinuses

 

 

Etiological agents for Botryomycosis include:

 

  • Staphylococcus aureus (most common)
  • Pseudomonas
  • Escherichia coli
  • Proteus
  • Streptococcus
    • Most lesions are on the limbs, but other sites including the perianal region and the face are affected.
    • Treatment: Flucloxacillin or erythromycin.

 

Option B: Carbuncle

 

  • It is a deep-seated cutaneous infection around a group of hair follicles with sieve-like multiple openings discharging pus.
  • Carbuncle is caused by Staphylococcus aureus

 

Below image depicts Carbuncle

 

 

Option C: Sycosis

 

  • A subacute or chronic infection that affects the entire depth of the follicle is known as sycosis.
  • It affects the area around the beard.
  • An oedematous erythematous follicular papule or pustule centred on a hair is the primary lesion.

 

Image shown below depicts Sycosis barbae:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Scarlet fever is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes, not Staphylococcus aureus, distinguishing it from other skin conditions like botryomycosis, carbuncle, and sycosis barbae, which are associated with Staphylococcus aureus.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition

Chapter 26, Page nos 26.16-26.17, 26.72

Andrew's Diseases of the Skin: Clinical Dermatology - 11th Edition Chapter 14, Page nos 245 - 246

questions.text: A child came to dermatological OPD with complaints of an itchy lesion over face. On microbiological examination Gram positive cocci arranged in pairs & chains are seen. All of the following are possible complications EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Rheumatic fever

 

Option C.

 

  • The above scenario is suggestive of streptococcal impetigo.
  • Rheumatic fever is a complication of streptococcal pharyngitis, not impetigo.

 

Characteristic features of Streptococcus pyogenes

 

  • Gram +ve cocci arranged in pairs & chains.

 

 

  • Beta haemolysis on blood agar & catalase negative test

 

Skin conditions associated ONLY WITH STREPTOCOCCI.

 

 

  • Not associated with carbuncle

 

The complications of streptococcal impetigo include:

 

  • Scarlet fever
  • Erythema multiforme
  • Erythema nodosum
  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.
  • Cellulitis

 

(NOT RHEUMATIC FEVER)

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rheumatic fever is not a complication typically associated with streptococcal skin infections but rather with streptococcal pharyngitis.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 26, Page no 26.13

questions.text: A 12-month-old male infant developed conjunctivitis which was managed with topical & oral antibiotics. A few days later, he developed fever, irritability, and skin tenderness followed by extensive peeling of the skin. On examination mucosa of eyes, oral cavity & genitalia were normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D.  Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome

 

Option D. 

 

  • The infant presents with a distant focus of infection (conjunctivitis) that is followed by generalized peeling of the skin and toxic state of the baby without any mucosal involvement (as Desmoglein-3 is not involved in Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome) which is suggestive of staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Syphilitic pemphigus:

 

Vesiculo-bullous lesions seen in early congenital syphilis.

 

Option B & C: In Stevens Johnson Syndrome & Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis

 

Mucosal involvement is prominent with Hemorrhagic crusts. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, characterized by fever, irritability, skin tenderness, and skin peeling, with an absence of mucosal involvement, in infants and young children.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 26, Page no 26.17

questions.text: A 45-year-old came to Dermatological OPD with a hyperpigmented asymptomatic rash over the axilla as shown below. Woods lamp examination shows coral pink fluorescence. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Erythrasma

 

Option B.

 

  • Coral pink or Coral red fluorescence on wood's lamp examination is characteristic of Erythrasma which is a skin infection caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum.

  • It is frequently seen in diabetics and immunocompromised patients and is linked to obesity, excessive sweating, and poor hygiene.

  • Lesions are hyperpigmented patches that are mostly asymptomatic.

  • The axilla, groin, intergluteal, and sub mammary areas are typically affected.

  • Coprophyrin III, which is produced by the bacterium, is what causes the coral pink or Coral red fluorescence on the Woods lamp.

 

 

  • Wood's lamp uses ultraviolet wavelength light at 365nm (320-400nm) with a peak at 365nm. The filter of the Wood's lamp is composed of Barium silicate and 9% Nickel oxide.

 

Table: Various diseases & their colour on woods lamp examination

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Erythrasma by its typical presentation of a well-demarcated, hyperpigmented rash in intertriginous areas and coral red or pink fluorescence under Wood's lamp examination.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4 page no 4.20

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition

Chapter 26 Page no 26.40

questions.text: A 1-year-old child is brought to the clinic with complaints of fever, irritability, poor oral intake, and skin lesions. Vitals examination revealed increased Heart rate (tachycardia present) and a temperature of 101 F. On examination of the skin, diffuse erythema is present along with flaccid bullae. The skin is moist, erythematous, and shiny. Some areas of the skin are desquamated, as shown in the image below. The culture from the lesions is positive for Staphylococcus aureus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Scalded Skin Syndrome

 

Option D.

 

Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS)

 

  • It is a condition caused by the exotoxins of Staphylococcus aureus, which can lead to the widespread formation of flaccid bullae that rupture easily, causing desquamation and erythematous, shiny skin underneath.
  • This clinical picture is consistent with the findings in the patient described: fever, irritability, poor oral intake, diffuse erythema, flaccid bullae, and positive culture for Staphylococcus aureus.
  • SSSS is particularly common in young children and infants.
  • Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis is an important differential if adults are having similar clinical features.
  • Differences between Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis and SSSS are given in the table below.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Congenital syphilis

 

  • It presents with various signs including snuffles, vesiculobullous rash, Hepatosplenomegaly, Hutchinson teeth and bony abnormalities.
  • Positive bacterial culture makes SSSS more likely diagnosis, though vesiculobullous lesions can be seen in both these conditions.

 

Option B. Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • It is an autoimmune disease that presents with flaccid bullae and erosions, but it is extremely rare in children and does not typically present with systemic symptoms such as fever or a positive bacterial culture.

 

Option C. Epidermolysis bullosa

 

  • It is a group of genetic disorders that present with blistering of the skin and mucous membranes in response to minor trauma since birth.
  • It would not cause fever, systemic symptoms, or a positive bacterial culture.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) based on the clinical presentation of fever, irritability, poor oral intake, diffuse erythema, flaccid bullae, shiny erythematous skin, desquamation, and a positive Staphylococcus aureus culture, especially in the paediatric population.Top of Form

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 26.13-26.16

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1265

Online resources:

https://dermnetnz.org/topics/sjs-ten-nursing

questions.text: A military soldier presents with rashes all over the body sparing the palms & soles. On examination, fever and lice were noted. Which of the following is responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Rickettsia prowazekii.

 

Option C.

 

Rickettsia prowazekii

 

  • It is the causative agent of epidemic typhus, which is transmitted by the human body louse.
  • The disease is characterized by a rash that typically starts on the trunk and spreads peripherally, sparing the palms and soles, fever, and systemic symptoms.
  • It is associated with overcrowding and poor hygiene, conditions that are often found in military camps or during wartime.

 

Diseases transmitted by Body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis)

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rickettsia akari

 

  • It causes rickettsialpox, not epidemic typhus.
  • Rickettsialpox is transmitted by mite bites and is characterized by an eschar at the site of the bite, followed by a vesicular rash and mild systemic symptoms.

 

Option B. Rickettsia conorii

 

  • It is the agent responsible for Mediterranean spotted fever, also known as Boutonneuse fever.
  • It is transmitted by dog ticks and presents with fever, a rash that also involves the palms and soles, and a characteristic tache noire (black spot) at the site of the tick bite.

 

Option D. Rickettsia typhi

 

  • It causes murine or endemic typhus, which is transmitted by flea bites.
  • The clinical presentation can be similar to epidemic typhus but is typically milder, and the rash also often involves the palms and soles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rickettsia prowazekii is the causative agent of epidemic typhus, which presents with fever, a rash sparing palms and soles, and lice infestation, conditions that can be prevalent in crowded military environments.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 26.76

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1319, 1511

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic with a one-week history of fever, headache, and myalgia. He reports a recent hiking trip in a rural area of Southeast Asia. On physical examination, he is found to have a maculopapular rash on his trunk and extremities and an eschar on his back, as shown in the image. Laboratory tests reveal thrombocytopenia and elevated hepatic transaminases. He denies any respiratory symptoms, gastrointestinal symptoms, or a history of similar episodes. Which of the following diseases is most likely depicted by the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Scrub typhus.

 

Option D.

 

Scrub typhus

 

  • It is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi, which is transmitted by the bite of an infected chigger (trombiculid mite).

 

 

  • The clinical presentation can include fever, headache, myalgia, and a maculopapular rash.
  • A hallmark of the disease is the presence of an eschar at the site of the mite bite, which is typically a black, crusted lesion surrounded by an erythematous halo, as seen in the provided image.
  • The patient's history of traveling to Southeast Asia and the presence of an eschar with accompanying symptoms strongly suggest scrub typhus.

 

MITES OF MEDICAL IMPORTANCE

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. COVID 19

 

  • It typically presents with respiratory symptoms such as cough, shortness of breath, and fever.
  • The skin manifestations of COVID-19, if present, do not usually include an eschar.

 

Option B. Malaria

 

  • It is characterized by cyclical fever, chills, and sweats.
  • It is caused by Plasmodium species and transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes.
  • Malaria does not present with an eschar.

 

Option C. RMSF (Rocky Mountain spotted fever)

 

  • It is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii, is transmitted by tick bites and presents with fever, headache, abdominal pain, and a rash that may start on the wrists and ankles before spreading; however, it does not typically present with an eschar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Scrub typhus by its clinical presentation, including the presence of an eschar at the site of a chigger bite, fever, headache, myalgia, and a maculopapular rash in a patient with a history of travel to an endemic area.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 26.79

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1326

Online resources:

https://dermnetnz.org/topics/scrub-typhus

choices.text: It is also known as pemphigus neonatorum.
Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a serious complication associated with this disease

questions.text: A six-year-old child presents to the clinic with a complaint of a rapidly spreading rash around the mouth. The mother notes that it started as a small red area that quickly erupted into blisters before forming the characteristic honey-coloured crusts. The child has no significant medical history and is up to date with vaccinations. On examination, there are no signs of systemic infection, and the lesions are localized around the mouth. The mother denies recent exposure to anyone with similar symptoms. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a serious complication associated with this disease.

 

Option D.

 

From the clinical case scenario the diagnosis we can make is:

 

Nonbullous impetigo/ Impetigo contagiosa:

 

  • It is a common bacterial skin infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus and sometimes by Streptococcus pyogenes.
  • It is characterized by honey-coloured crusts as shown in the image below, often following a blister that has ruptured.

 

 

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis can occur after skin infections with nephritogenic strains of streptococci, it is a serious complication that requires monitoring.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bacteria targeting desmoglein 1: It is characteristic of Bullous impetigo, not non bullous form.

 

Option B. It is also known as pemphigus neonatorum: Pemphigus neonatorum is the other name for Bullous Impetigo.

 

Option C. Mostly involves trunk: Nonbullous impetigo commonly presents around the mouth and nose, not predominantly on the trunk.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nonbullous impetigo is a common pediatric skin infection characterized by honey-coloured crusts usually around the mouth and nose, understanding that it is caused by Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus and can occasionally lead to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis as a serious complication.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 26.14

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1260

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with an abscess containing pus. Gram stain of the organism obtained from the pus is shown in the image below. Which of the following diseases is NOT caused associated with this organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Scarlet fever

 

Option B.

 

Scarlet fever: This disease is primarily caused by group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) and not Staphylococcus aureus.

 

  • The given image depicts grape-like clusters of gram-positive staphylococci.
  • Gram-positive staphylococcus, particularly Staphylococcus aureus, is known to be responsible for various clinical conditions

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute paronychia:  Staphylococcus aureus can cause acute paronychia, an infection of the nail fold, commonly seen in individuals who bite their nails or have frequent exposure to moisture.

 

Option C. Sycosis barbae:  Staphylococcus aureus can indeed cause sycosis barbae, which is a bacterial infection of the beard area.

 

Option D. Toxic shock syndrome:  Staphylococcus aureus, specifically strains producing toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1), is a well-known cause of toxic shock syndrome.

 

Involvement of Staphylococcus aureus in cutaneous disease:

 

 

Involvement of streptococci (mostly group A) in cutaneous disease

 

 

Skin conditions associated ONLY WITH STREPTOCOCCI.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Scarlet fever is NOT caused by Staphylococcus aureus but rather by group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes).

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 26.6

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1268

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents with a severe blistering skin condition. On examination, you observe extensive skin denudation with a positive Nikolsky sign. Which among the following findings in history and/or examination is in favour of the diagnosis of Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) and helps rule out the diagnosis of Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Absence of oral mucosal involvement"

 

Option C.

 

Absence of oral mucosal involvement:

 

  • Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) typically spares the oral mucosa, while Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN) often involves the oral mucosa.
  • This finding is more indicative of SSSS and can help rule out TEN.
  • This is in favor of the diagnosis of Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) and helps rule out the diagnosis of Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN).
  • Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) and Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN) are severe blistering skin conditions, but they have different aetiologies and clinical characteristics, which have been summarised in the table below.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Presence of systemic symptoms:

 

  • Both SSSS and TEN can present with systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, and weakness.
  • This finding doesn't specifically differentiate between the two conditions.

 

Option B. Skin denudation:

 

  • Both SSSS and TEN are characterized by skin denudation or blistering.
  • This finding is common to both conditions and doesn't help distinguish between them.

 

Option D. Antibiotic usage:

 

  • SSSS is often associated with a primary Staphylococcus aureus infection, whereas TEN is frequently triggered by medications, particularly antibiotics.
  • The presence of antibiotic usage is more suggestive of TEN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Differentiating between Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) and Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN) is crucial in managing these severe skin conditions - The absence of oral mucosal involvement is a characteristic feature of SSSS, while TEN often presents with mucosal involvement.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 26.28

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1266

questions.text: Gram stain revealed the following organism as shown in the image below. Which of the following diseases is caused by it?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ecthyma

 

Option A.

 

Gram stain is suggestive of Streptococcus, which is a gram-positive bacterium with chain like arrangement.

 

 

Image depicts Ecthyma, which presents as thick black adherent crust, it can be caused by staphylococcus and streptococcus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B:

 

 

Image depicts Angular infarct & petechiae seen in Meningococcal infection caused by Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Option C:

 

 

Image depicts Eschar surrounded by small vesicles (Malignant Pustule) seen in Anthrax Caused by Bacillus anthracis.

 

Option D:

 

 

Image depicts Folliculitis caused by Staphylococcus aureus

 

Involvement of Staphylococcus aureus in cutaneous disease

 

 

Involvement of streptococci (mostly group A) in cutaneous disease

 

 

Skin conditions associated ONLY WITH STREPTOCOCCI.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Gram stain findings of bacterium with chain like arrangement is Streptococcus and remember the diseases caused by gram positive organisms like Staphylococcus & Streptococcus.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 26.17

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1265

Online resources:

https://dermnetnz.org/topics/anthrax

choices.text: Can be caused by both staphylococcus and streptococcus
It extends deep into subcutaneous tissues
It feels hard on palpation

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented with well demarcated redness over leg as shown in the image below. It was extremely painful. Which of the following statement is true regarding it?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It feels hard on palpation.

 

Option C.

 

  • Erysipelas is characterized by well-demarcated redness and warmth, and it often feels firm or raised on palpation due to the inflammatory response.
  • Therefore, this statement is true.
  • Clinical image shows well defined erythematous plaques over leg.
  • Differential diagnosis of tender erythematous plaques over leg are erysipelas and cellulitis.
  • Erysipelas is a skin infection that typically presents with well-demarcated redness, warmth, and pain, most commonly affecting the lower extremities.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Can be caused by both Staphylococcus and Streptococcus:

 

  • Erysipelas is caused by Streptococcus, especially Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes).
  • Staphylococcus is not a causative agent for erysipelas.
  • Therefore, this statement is not true.

 

Option B. It extends deep into subcutaneous tissues:

 

  • Erysipelas typically involves the upper layers of the skin and the superficial dermis but does not extend deep into subcutaneous tissues.
  • It is more superficial compared to cellulitis.
  • Therefore, this statement is not true.

 

 

Option D. It never involves the ear:

 

  • Erysipelas can affect various parts of the body, including the ear (Milian's Ear Sign).
  • Ear involvement is called Milian's ear sign, and it is a feature distinguishing erysipelas from cellulitis, because the pinna has no deeper dermis and subcutaneous tissue .

 

 

  • It is not restricted to any specific anatomical location.
  • Therefore, this statement is not true.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Erysipelas is an acute bacterial skin infection, primarily caused by Streptococcus, and is characterized by well-demarcated, painful, warm, and often firm or raised skin lesions.
  • It can affect various parts of the body, including the ear.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 26.19

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1269

questions.text: A 6-year-old female presented with complaints of fever associated with chills, sore throat, and facial rash for 5 days. Physical examination reveals an erythematous pharynx without exudates and perioral honey-coloured crusts as shown in the image below. What is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Topical antibiotics

 

Option D.

 

  • Topical antibiotics, such as mupirocin or fusidic acid, are the most appropriate therapy for impetigo.
  • They target the bacteria responsible for the infection.

 

The most appropriate therapy for impetigo is:

 

  • The clinical presentation of a 6-year-old female with fever, sore throat, and facial rash, along with the characteristic honey colored crust is suggestive of Non Bullous impetigo.
  • Non Bullous impetigo is a bacterial skin infection most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes.
  • The mainstay of treatment for impetigo is topical antibiotics.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Isotretinoin ointment:

 

  • Isotretinoin is not indicated for the treatment of bacterial infections like impetigo.

 

Option B. Topical steroids:

 

  • Topical steroids are contraindicated in impetigo because they can exacerbate bacterial skin infections.

 

Option C. Topical salicylic acid:

 

  • Topical salicylic acid is not indicated for the treatment of bacterial infections like impetigo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Impetigo is a common bacterial skin infection, and the treatment of choice is topical antibiotics.
  • The use of topical antibiotics helps to target and eliminate the causative bacteria, such as Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 26.15

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1261

questions.text: A 45-year-old butcher presents with a painful, erythematous, and slightly swollen lesion on his left hand as shown in the image below. He reports that the symptoms started a few days after he handled some raw fish. The lesion has well-defined borders and does not present with lymphangitic streaking. His vital signs are stable, and he has no fever. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Erysipeloid

 

Option B.

 

  • It is a skin infection caused by the bacterium Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae, commonly seen in individuals who handle fish, meat, or poultry.
  • The presentation is typically a localized skin infection with well-defined margins, often on the hands, and the absence of systemic symptoms like fever.
  • The patient's occupation and history of handling raw fish strongly point towards this diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Impetigo:

 

  • It is a superficial skin infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes, characterized by honey-colored crusts.
  • It commonly affects children and is not typically associated with occupational exposure.

 

Option C. Ecthyma:

 

  • It is a deeper form of impetigo penetrating into the dermis, often presenting with ulcerative lesions covered by a crust.
  • It is not consistent with the patient’s occupational history or clinical presentation.

 

Option D. Scalded skin syndrome:

 

  • It is caused by exfoliative toxins of Staphylococcus aureus, typically presents with widespread erythema, fever, and skin sloughing.
  • The localized nature of this patient's lesion and the absence of systemic symptoms make this diagnosis unlikely.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Identify Erysipeloid as a localized skin infection often associated with occupational exposure to fish, meat, or poultry, presenting with well-defined, erythematous lesions, usually without systemic symptoms.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 26.46

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1278

questions.text: A 30-year-old male marathon runner presents to the clinic with complaints of malodour and multiple small, crater-like depressions on the weight-bearing parts of his feet as shown in the image below. He mentions the problem seems to worsen with his running schedule, especially in his occlusive footwear. Physical examination reveals numerous, discrete, 1-3 mm pits on the soles of his feet. There is no scaling or interdigital involvement. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pitted keratolysis

 

Option C.

 

Pitted keratolysis

 

  • It is a due to infection by Corynebacterium / Kytococcus sedentarius. characterized by pitted, crater-like depressions on the soles of the feet and is often associated with a foul odour.
  • The pits are produced by serine proteases that can degrade keratin in the horny layer.
  • It is commonly seen in individuals whose feet are subjected to prolonged sweating, as in the case of this marathon runner using occlusive footwear.
  • The lack of scaling or interdigital involvement, which is commonly seen in tinea pedis, and the specific presentation of pitted lesions help differentiate this condition from the others listed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tinea pedis

 

  • It is a fungal infection that typically presents with scaling and maceration, especially between the toes, and might not have the distinct pitted appearance.

 

 

Option B. Superficial plantar warts

 

  • It is caused by human papillomavirus, often have a cauliflower-like appearance and may contain small black thrombosed capillaries as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option C. Candidiasis

 

  • It tends to affect warm, moist areas like skin folds and the interdigital spaces, and is often associated with erythema and scaling, unlike the presentation in this scenario.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pitted keratolysis clinical presentation - Small, crater-like depressions on the soles of the feet, often with an associated foul odor, and understand that it is typically seen in individuals with excessive foot sweating and those who wear occlusive footwear.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 26.42

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1276

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with acute myeloid leukemia presents to the emergency department with a two-day history of fever, chills, and a painful skin lesion. On physical examination, she has a rapidly expanding erythematous lesion on her chest with a black necrotic centre as shown in the image below. She is currently neutropenic due to recent chemotherapy. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of her skin lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pseudomonas septicaemia

 

Option A.


Ecthyma gangrenosum

 

  • It is a skin manifestation that is strongly associated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection, particularly in the setting of bacteremia and immunosuppression.
  • The patient's neutropenia, a result of chemotherapy for acute myeloid leukemia, increases her risk for opportunistic infections including Pseudomonas, which can lead to septicaemia and characteristic skin lesions.
  • These lesions typically present as erythematous or purpuric macules that rapidly evolve into necrotic ulcers with a black eschar.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hansen’s disease or leprosy:

 

  • It is a chronic infection caused by Mycobacterium leprae and presents with skin and peripheral nerve involvement over months to years, not acutely.

 

Option C. Parapox virus septicaemia:

 

  • It is not a recognized medical condition.
  • Parapox virus infections are typically associated with orf, which presents with Nodular lesions, weeping pustules on hands/fingers in individuals who have contact with sheep and goats.

 

 

Option D. Staphylococcal septicaemia:

 

  • It can cause a variety of skin manifestations, including abscesses or cellulitis, but the distinctive necrotic lesions are more characteristic of Pseudomonas infection in the context of ecthyma gangrenosum.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ecthyma gangrenosum is a cutaneous sign of Pseudomonas aeruginosa septicaemia, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those with neutropenia secondary to chemotherapy.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 30.49

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1281, 1437

questions.text: Match the wood lamp findings with the respective diseases.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1-e,2-c,3-d,4-b

 

Option B.

 

  • Woods lamp: It uses ultraviolet wavelength light, 320-400nm (peak 365nm).

  • Filter of woods lamp is made up of Barium silicate & 9% Nickel oxide.

  • It is used in dermatology to detect several conditions based on how the light is absorbed or reflected by the skin.

 

Correct matches:

 

 

 

 

 

 

Table: Various diseases & their colour on woods lamp examination

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Wood's lamp uses UVA light with a wavelength of 365nm (320-400 nm) for the diagnosis of various skin conditions based on the fluorescence characteristics of the skin under this specific range of ultraviolet light.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4 page no 4.20

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition, Chapter 26 Page no 26.40

Image source: https://dermnetnz.org/assets/Uploads/bacterial/erythrasma13__WatermarkedWyJXYXRlcm1hcmtlZCJd.jpg

questions.text: In a diabetic patient, the following lesions are present in the armpit. What would be observed during a Wood's lamp examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Coral red fluorescence.

 

Option B.

 

  • The clinical scenario of a diabetic patient, along with the observed hyperpigmented lesion in axilla strongly suggests erythrasma.
  • Coral-red fluorescence under Wood's lamp examination is the characteristic finding in this disease.

 

 

Erythrasma:

 

  • It is a skin infection caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum. This condition is commonly seen in individuals with diabetes and weakened immune systems and is associated with factors such as obesity, excessive sweating, and poor hygiene.
  • The characteristic feature of erythrasma is the presence of hyperpigmented patches that are typically asymptomatic. These patches commonly appear in areas like the axilla, groin, intergluteal, and sub-mammary regions.
  • The coral pink fluorescence observed during Wood's lamp examination is a defining feature of erythrasma and is caused by coproporphyrin III, a pigment produced by the bacterium.

 

 

  • Wood's lamp uses ultraviolet wavelength light at 365nm (320-400nm) with a peak at 365nm. The filter of the Wood's lamp is composed of Barium silicate and 9% Nickel oxide.

 

Table: Various diseases & their colour on woods lamp examination

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Wood's lamp uses UVA light with a wavelength of 365nm (320-400 nm) for the diagnosis of various skin conditions based on the fluorescence characteristics of the skin under this specific range of ultraviolet light.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4 page no 4.20

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition, Chapter 26 Page no 26.40

Image source: https://dermnetnz.org/assets/Uploads/bacterial/erythrasma13__WatermarkedWyJXYXRlcm1hcmtlZCJd.jpg

choices.text: Healing brown recluse spider bite

questions.text: Which of the following differentials should not be considered for the lesion seen in the image developed in a forest officer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD)

 

Option B.

 

  • KFD is a tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever endemic in South India.
  • The primary clinical manifestations of KFD are fever, headache, severe muscle pain, followed by haemorrhagic symptoms like haemorrhages in the skin, mucosa & viscera, petechial lesions are characteristic skin lesions observed.
  • It is more known for its neurological and hemorrhagic manifestations but NOT Eschar.

 

Eschar can be noted in the given image, and Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) is not a possible differential diagnosis for eschar.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Scrub typhus (chigger-borne typhus)

 

  • The infective agent of scrub typhus, Orientia tsutsugamushi (Previously known as Rickettsia tsutsugamushi), is conveyed to humans from its natural rodent reservoir by the bites of the Trombiculid mite.

 

 

  • Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers.
  • The incubation period is 1- 3 weeks. The primary lesion, or eschar, is a firm papule up to 1 mm in diameter surmounted by a vesicle, which dries to form a black crust.

 

Option C: Cutaneous anthrax (Hide porters’ disease)

 

  • Anthrax is a zoonotic infection with Bacillus anthracis.
  • Between 1 and 5 days after infection, an irritable papule develops at the site of inoculation. A bulla on a red oedematous base soon follows.
  • The bulla ruptures and forms a haemorrhagic crust which will undergo necrosis. Surrounding this several satellite lesions filled with serum or yellow fluid are arranged around a central necrotic lesion which is covered by a black eschar.
  • This is called as Malignant pustule as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option D: Healing brown recluse spider bite.

 

Bite of Loxosceles reclusa (Loxoscelism) → Target lesion develops → Development of eschar → Heals with Ulcer formation.

 

Diseases / Skin conditions presenting with ESCHAR formation:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Kyasanur Forest Disease tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever, primarily presenting with haemorrhagic and neurological symptoms, should not be considered for skin lesion, Eschar, unlike the other mentioned differentials.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 26.79, 34.33

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 249, 250, 415, 530

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with a history of diarrhoea and neurogenic bladder requiring intermittent self-catheterization presents to the clinic with a complaint of a new rash around his groin. On examination, you note a patch of erythematous skin with multiple pustules. A swab of the area grows a gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic bacterium. Considering the patient's medical history and the typical skin flora that can be found in the groin area due to faecal contamination, which organism is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Escherichia coli

 

Option D.

 

Although E. coli is not commonly part of the normal skin flora, it is a well-known colonizer of the intestinal tract. In this patient, the presence of E. coli on the skin is likely due to fecal contamination, which can occur in individuals with conditions that affect normal bowel or bladder function, such as neurogenic bladder. The intermittent self-catheterization and the proximity of the groin to the perianal area increase the risk of such contamination.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus epidermidis and B. Staphylococcus aureus

 

  • They are part of the normal skin flora.
  • S. aureus can cause skin infections, but the presence of a gram-negative organism in the culture points away from these bacteria.

 

Option C. Candida albicans: It is a common cause of fungal infections in skin folds but would not present as a gram-negative bacterium in cultures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • E. coli is not typically part of the normal skin flora, it can be present in certain areas such as the groin due to Fecal contamination, particularly in patients with conditions that affect normal bowel or bladder function.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 2.13, 26.3
